reviewText:
One Manga Day is a Visual Novel both Developed and Published by DeXP. The game appears to have been made using a combination of default models from Manga Maker ComiPo! and some other Visual Novel creation software. The game advertises a couple of hours of gameplay and unfortunately I can't even confirm or deny this fact since I stopped playing after only 15 minutes.

One Manga Day's story is completely random and quite frankly difficult to follow at all. First, you're randomly approached to work for a company that specializes in translating manga and then 2 minutes later you are officially trained in your profession of choice and ready to work. Follow this up with an unaesthetically pleasing user interface and a mash up of weird/cringeworthy scenes and the result is One Manga Day.

To be honest, the game is free so you can easy download the 100 or so megabytes and play it for yourself, but don't expect much because the quality of this game appears to have been lost in translation"."

reviewText:
Well that was about as humouros as a well-made fanfic.
Considering they got 2 translations done in a month is impressive. Unfortunately the quality control of the english script is lacking in proofreading skills. Something the game actually makes fun of at times.
So the art is borrowing from a manga making program, so nothing good, but it gets the job done.
I blazed through this will all achievements in an hour so you won't be wasting a day on this like a huge visual novel.
Just sit down, have a good time piecing together this crazy nonsense, get to the funny scenarios and enjoy.
Besides, this is one of the most lively (and free) visual novels that I've seen on Steam. The humor reminded me of Without Within. Both games are getting successors so I consider this a step in the right comedic direction. Not to the Gintama standard but more like a series of Nichijo skits. Good in small doses and clever when pieced together.

Give it a try and maybe create some of your own ideas. 6/10 ~RB

I fixed the description: Manga is the Japanese word for comic. In the west, the term has been calqued to refer specifically to Japanese comics despite not actually holding this distinction in Japan. The problem for most people is, as they believe everything they read and hear, they take their understanding of such terms as their universal meaning; that's why someone has to come in and localize everything for them so that it fits their linguistic register and matches their specific understanding of foreign words. Is one man able to do this? Is there more to his team's relationships other than business (guess that answers the previous rhetorical question)? Can everything in a translator's life be simple and clear (um.. what)?

But yeah, it is kind of ironic that, for a game about the translation process, the devs entirely overlook how meanings shift as words are borrowed and instead present the western meaning of a Japanese word as its only meaning.

Anyway, the game sounds like stereotypical pandering to teen nerds who want to grow up to move to Japan and become manga anime translators after first doing the jet program.

That said, it is free and the dev’s first creation so hell, play it if you're interested. The English translation is god awful. Machine translated I think. Not that much is lost because of it. Could be worth a laugh though. Admittedly, I found the game description more interesting than the actual game.

I fixed the description: Manga is the Japanese word for comic. In the west, the term has been calqued to refer specifically to Japanese comics despite not actually holding this distinction in Japan. The problem for most people is, as they believe everything they read and hear, they take their understanding of such terms as their universal meaning; that's why someone has to come in and localize everything for them so that it fits their linguistic register and matches their specific understanding of foreign words. Is one man able to do this? Is there more to his team's relationships other than business (guess that answers the previous rhetorical question)? Can everything in a translator's life be simple and clear (um.. what)?

But yeah, it is kind of ironic that, for a game about the translation process, the devs entirely overlook how meanings shift as words are borrowed and instead present the western meaning of a Japanese word as its only meaning.

Anyway, the game sounds like stereotypical pandering to teen nerds who want to grow up to move to Japan and become manga anime translators after first doing the jet program.

That said, it is free and the dev’s first creation so hell, play it if you're interested. The English translation is god awful. Machine translated I think. Not that much is lost because of it. Could be worth a laugh though. Admittedly, I found the game description more interesting than the actual game.

- There's achievements!

The bg music is not grating or anything special, but its not in the way or anything. The art style is fine, I guess. The Voices are pretty good with the exception of the Pink Aloof girl, who is far too overdone, even for a cartoonish style. Also there is an orange haired girl who seems to be lacking audio in some parts.


The pacing is terrible. There is no way around that. The PoV changes constantly from 3rd omniescent to 1st person main character (unless you, the main acharacter somehow have god powers of some sort, which is not explained in game). And while there is a few parts in the begining that are about working in a manga translation studio, it quickly devolves into a load of weird awkwardness.

The characters aren't well defined, except the few that are, and most of which are unlikeable. The creepy stalker guy who breaks into the blonde's house to spy on her? And he's done it before? And we're suppoed to like he ending wher he ends up with the girl he is STALKING? Gross. Theres hardly any more concrete ones. The Blond Girl probably has the most attention put to, apparently. Even a character like the army-boss head of staff woman is just a one trick pony.

Now I didn't play with the Bonus Content. But the base game is all over the place, the characters are sloppily defined at best...I feel like someone is trying to convince me that this IDEA is good, so they can start actually making the game...but its an actual game. I feel like its missing half the plot. You have to guess wtf is going on more than half the time.



It was an interesting game, I guess? Was a good idea at least. Poorly executed.

2/10 rating: good voice and bg music, and the characters can be differentiated physically by hights and silhuettes and colours, at least (even if the style is a sameface style, cant get around that). The beginning with the actual information was pretty neat, too, if a little summarised and simplified.



Do I recomend this? Not really. Its a neat idea but so badly put together. The acheivements are pretty easy to get and in less than an hour, even without any assistance. So if you want to have at least one perfect game, this is a safe bet (if you can pull yourself through the broken storyline, that is).

reviewText:
The bg music is not grating or anything special, but its not in the way or anything. The art style is fine, I guess. The Voices are pretty good with the exception of the Pink Aloof girl, who is far too overdone, even for a cartoonish style. Also there is an orange haired girl who seems to be lacking audio in some parts.


The pacing is terrible. There is no way around that. The PoV changes constantly from 3rd omniescent to 1st person main character (unless you, the main acharacter somehow have god powers of some sort, which is not explained in game). And while there is a few parts in the begining that are about working in a manga translation studio, it quickly devolves into a load of weird awkwardness.

The characters aren't well defined, except the few that are, and most of which are unlikeable. The creepy stalker guy who breaks into the blonde's house to spy on her? And he's done it before? And we're suppoed to like he ending wher he ends up with the girl he is STALKING? Gross. Theres hardly any more concrete ones. The Blond Girl probably has the most attention put to, apparently. Even a character like the army-boss head of staff woman is just a one trick pony.

Now I didn't play with the Bonus Content. But the base game is all over the place, the characters are sloppily defined at best...I feel like someone is trying to convince me that this IDEA is good, so they can start actually making the game...but its an actual game. I feel like its missing half the plot. You have to guess wtf is going on more than half the time.



It was an interesting game, I guess? Was a good idea at least. Poorly executed.

2/10 rating: good voice and bg music, and the characters can be differentiated physically by hights and silhuettes and colours, at least (even if the style is a sameface style, cant get around that). The beginning with the actual information was pretty neat, too, if a little summarised and simplified.



Do I recomend this? Not really. Its a neat idea but so badly put together. The acheivements are pretty easy to get and in less than an hour, even without any assistance. So if you want to have at least one perfect game, this is a safe bet (if you can pull yourself through the broken storyline, that is).

reviewText:
This was weird, like a drugged dream.

Pros:
+ Some information about the process of manga translation and the point of different roles in a manga translator team
+ Free achievements

Cons:
- Tons and tons of inane dialogue. (The Skip button is your friend.) I don't know what the writer(s) smoked when they wrote this game, but it must be a strong one.
- A huge cast of characters, all of them are one-note-joke personalities.
- Annoying, looping music, some weird sound effects (that maniacal laughter...)
- Low quality graphics with a mixture of anime style character sprites and digitally painted backgrounds
- The writer(s) don't have a strong grasp on English, there are many weird phrasings, and quite a few sentences that (I guess) are supposed to be funny, but don't make any sense.
- From what little I read of the non-manga-related dialogues there's a lot of problematic content, like sexist dialogue options, joking about suicide, and at one point you can only proceed by tricking a female character into gradually undressing O.o

Verdict£0.00 is truly the correct price for this game. Only get it for the achievements.

Whatever information it tells you about manga translation you can probably find with 5 minutes of googling, and it provides no further value.
